title: Quake-detecting system a failure
author: Dallas Morning News
text: MEXICO CITY - This city's vaunted earthquake-warning system, installed with great fanfare several months ago, has been deactivated after a power failure sent a false alarm that scared millions of residents    The false alarm Tuesday night was the second major malfunction of the new system, which relies on radio signals to warn the 20 million residents of Mexico City of an approaching quake measuring 6.0 or above on the Richter scale.    The system did not alert the public Oct. 24 when a quake measuring 6.8 on the Richter scale rattled Mexico City. The quake caused power outages and panic as well as public skepticism about the monitoring system that increased with this week's false alarm.   The system will be changed so a general alarm will not be sounded unless the control center in Mexico City receives earthquake signals from two warning stations.
